awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Influence of natural ice microstructure on rheology in general shear: in-situ studies in the Alaska Range
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the loss of ice from glaciers and ice sheets, and the resulting sea-level rise, is of critical importance. Both the Greenland and Antarctic Ice Sheets, as well as mountain glaciers, discharge primarily though rivers of ice; understanding what controls the type of flow that occurs in these rivers of ice is therefore central to understanding and predicting sea-level rise. Among the least-understood factors that are thought to be important in affecting ice flow is internal strength of the ice near the sides of a flowing glacier. This viscous strength, in turn, may be affected by the micro-scale structure of the ice crystals in the glacier. The investigators propose to examine these relationships in detail on Jarvis Glacier, in the eastern Alaska Range, with the ultimate goal of being able to represent the effects of microstructure in numerical models of glacial flow.

To do this, the investigators will first use surface velocity measurements, knowledge of the glacier geometry derived from ground penetrating radar, and numerical modeling to identify a site for drilling. They will then collect surface-to-bed cores across lateral and vertical flow gradients. Velocity and temperature measurements derived from the boreholes will complement the surface measurements and allow the investigators to produce a more sophisticated three-dimensional numerical model to test the sensitivity of flow patterns to the mechanical structure within the study area. They will compare the microstructure (e.g., grain size distribution, crystallographic fabric) in the ice cores to the in-situ and modeled velocities and temperatures. Although experiments suggest that variations in the intensity and orientation of the crystallographic fabric can result in up to a ten-fold difference in flow strength, there are very few in-situ observational studies of the microstructural architecture of streaming ice; most studies of ice microstructure come from ice divides, where flow rates are slowest. At the end of this project, the investigators aim to have determined (1) the degree to which fabrics formed in the study area are predictable based on ice kinematics, and (2) the relationship among measured crystallographic orientation fabric intensity, grain size, temperature, and ice viscosity as calculated through numerical models. A correlation between fabric and viscous strength would suggest that remote sensing techniques such as radar and seismic anisotropy could become an even more powerful method for identifying the rheological structure of ice. Alternatively, the lack of a strong link between viscous strength and fabric indicates that other factors exert significant control on the rheological properties. Therefore, the results of the proposed project, whatever the correlation between microstructure and viscous strength, should improve quantitative understanding of the physical laws governing streaming ice and improve future predictions of ice mass balance. The project would support and involve both graduate and undergraduate students. The project's numerical models will be developed into a publicly available web-based graphical user interface for use by other researchers and in the classroom.

por.por_cntn:
Globally, we have only medium confidence in predicting glacier flow rates, in part because of uncertainty in ice viscosity. Although we recognize how temperature, water content, and microscale structures affect ice flow, we do not have a robust understanding of how these factors are distributed in natural settings. To address this shortcoming and help improve our quantitative understanding of how ice flows, we collected and examined ice cores from the edge of a glacier in Alaska. We chose the location, on the glacier that feeds Jarvis Creek south of Delta Junction, so we could collect cores that reached the glacier bed at multiple locations near the lateral margin. In the end, we described in detail the crystallographic structure of two cores that reached bed, one 80m long and one 18m long, located 100m and 25m from the edge of the glacier. We described other features, including grain size, grain shape, and bubble aspect ratio, from those two cores plus an additional 30m-long core collected between the first two.

These cores displayed systematic changes in grain size and shape, as well as bubble aspect ratio. Grain size and shape depend on a number of factors, including temperature, deformation rate and amount, water content, and impurity content. Bubbles in glaciers begin as spheres and become ellipsoids as the ice deforms, so bubble aspect ratio tracks how much the ice has deformed. However, our main focus was to measure the orientation of the ice crystals that make up the core. We focused on that parameter because ice crystals are highly mechanically anisotropic: they deform much more easily in one direction than another, similar to a deck of cards, and this can exert significant control on how fast glaciers flow. The orientation of ice crystals also depends on a number of factors, but is principally controlled by deformation magnitude, as long as that deformation has occurred in a consistent geometry. To our knowledge, our study is the first to report fabric from surface to bed within the margin of a temperate glacier, and only the third from any lateral margin.

Grain shape, grain size, bubble aspect ratio, and crystallographic fabric all vary with proximity to the lateral margin. Grains are less circular and larger, and bubbles are more elongate nearer the margin. Crystallographic axes closer to the margin are slightly more concentrated and fewer c-axes are steeply inclined. Although variable, the differences in these factors do not appear sufficient to have driven the contrasting deformation, as indicated by the bubbles, between the edge and middle of the glacier. This leads us to think that in the case of our studied glacier, forces that concentrated along the irregular rock-ice boundary are primarily responsible. However, we are not able to test that idea at this time.

The study site has abundant water at the glacier base and in ice pore spaces, its average temperature is warmer than -2˚C, and the studied ice lies less than a kilometer from the source. All of these factors make it difficult for ice crystals to align during flow. Because we do see some alignment, albeit weak, we believe that most lateral margins of glacier margins, where conditions are more favorable, will develop a significant crystallographic orientation fabric, likely strong enough to exert a mechanical effect on flow rates.

To understand the potential mechanical impact of ice crystal alignment, and the comparison with temperature, we performed a series of numerical models measuring the influence of those factors on overall ice flow. In this part of the project, we focused on the total ice discharge, rather than the strength of the ice at any given point, because total discharge is largely what controls how fast ice is decreasing from the land and contributing to sea level rise.

Results show that realistic ice crystal orientation distributions have the potential to increase ice flux on the order of 15%, similar to what a 10˚C increase in temperature causes. The impact can be both larger and smaller by changing the degree of ice crystal alignment and temperature different amounts and at different locations throughout the glacier. Changing both temperature and the degree of crystal alignment at the same time can lead to non-linear effects, amplifying the influence of either factor alone.

Our direct study of an Alaskan glacier and numerical exploration of ice flow indicates that ice crystal orientation and concentration play a controlling role in determining ice kinematics. Therefore, studies aiming to reproduce or predict ice flow must account for these factors.
